text:
My journey into the industry is a little varied but pretty similar to a lot of peoples.

I studied computer games design and production at university which taught a broad range of subjects some better than others. For my Dissertation I researched subtle player navigation techniques and how they can used to guide player. This had a heavy emphasis on level design which was what I wanted to specialise in. I built a demo that incorporated some of the techniques.

I didnt do a placement year and went straight into my final year. During final year I interned as QA and a designer for nosebleed interactive which allowed me to see what it was like to work on a live project. This meant shortly after graduating I had been credited on a released game. This isn't a opportunity that will be available to everyone but one I happened to discover through networking within the local industry.

Coatsink was my first full time gig where I started out as a junior designer and worked my way to becoming a Lead. In my time there I shipped 5 titles and worked quite heavily in VR. All the games I helped develop there were made using Unity.  I was with the company for for just over 3 and half years before leaving to go freelance while I figured out what I wanted to do next.

While freelancing I worked closely with Pocket Money games where I helped the studio to consolidate its portfolio and get a handful of projects off the ground. I helped put together the studios booth and demos for EGX REZZED 2019. One of the main projects during my time there was the Superhot quest port.

Then in May of 2019 I moved to Brighton and joined Hangar 13 as a level designer.

Other things I have been involved in/done:
• Established a game dev meet in Newcastle 
• Create and ran a Unity User group in Newcastle
• Helped to create and curiate speakers for NOVA game Conference 
• MCV/Develop 30 under 30 2019
• Full Bafta member
